summary: explore edge cases around db running as part of a module
description: summary we need to explore options on how to run ikasan standalone module with db persisting data to a local file
there are three options being reviewed for db runtime connection configuration
embedded mode in embedded mode an application opens a database from within the same jvm using jdbc
this is the fastest and easiest connection mode
the disadvantage is that a database may only be open in one virtual machine and class loader at any time
as in all modes both persistent and databases are supported
there is no limit on the number of database open concurrently or on the number of open connections
server mode when using the server mode sometimes called remote mode or mode an application opens a database remotely using the jdbc or odbc api
a server needs to be started within the same or another virtual machine or on another computer
many applications can connect to the same database at the same time by connecting to this server
internally the server process opens the in embedded mode
the server mode is slower than the embedded mode because all data is transferred over as in all modes both persistent and databases are supported
there is no limit on the number of database open concurrently per server or on the number of open connections
mixed mode the mixed mode is a combination of the embedded and the server mode

the first application that connects to a database does that in embedded mode but also starts a server so that other applications running in different processes or virtual machines can concurrently access the same data
the local connections are as fast as if the database is used in just the embedded mode while the remote connections are a bit slower

the server can be started and stopped from within the application using the server api or automatically automatic mixed when using the automatic mixed mode all clients that want to connect to the database no matter if it's an local or remote connection can do so using the exact same database url
each jira attached to this story covers the testing of the above modes
in addition we need to review the springboot console to see if this has any value

for example a scheduledconsumer with the default quartzmessageprovider and hashedmanagedidentifierservice gives a different jobexecutioncontext and therefore different event id on each recovery attempt

in general if a consumer is this is not the case and the event ids are generated in an idempotent manner to resolve all these scenarios if there is no identifier provided to the recovery manager first scenario then we can safely cancel any jobs associated with the given recoverymanager instance since there is one per flow when we call flow.stop or exit recovery if a consumer is multi threaded we can safely assume any identifiers are the same per recovery attempt and can use these to track which messages via the event ids are in recovery and only cancel when all eventids are out of recovery or stop is called

we use the thread id here since it may change between invocations of the recovery jms may use different threads to receive on otherwise we need to assume the consumer may not provide an idempotent event id so track the identifiers in the same way as the previous

summary: ability for initiators to invoke existing lifecycle hooks on resources used within flow components
description: at present resources on the left side of the initiator which have lifecycles such as a jca connector are accessible via the initiator as the initiator has a handle on that resource
this allows these resources to be stopped and started by the initiator as required

resources on the right hand side of the initiator are not known by either the initiator or the flows that encompass components utilising those resources hence those resources are not managed within the scope of an initiator the attached diagram currentflowimplementation.jpg provides an overview of this
this creates problems when trying to stop resources used by components in the flow such as connections to external systems
the only effective way to stop these is either via the jmx console by removing connections from their pool or by bouncing the application server
both are less than ideal
there are a number of options which can address this issue

however we really want to keep the initiator as the controller of the flows therefore the initiator should really be calling a start managed resource and stop managed resources on a flow as part of the initiator accordingly
below are two lightweight approaches which differ only slightly in their implementation
add startmanagedresources and stopmanagedresources to the flow interface
each of these methods can be called by the initiator on the existing initiator methods
care should be taken to ensure flow resources are started before the initiator starts its own resources and conversely stops its own resources before stopping the flow resources
within the flow implementation any flow components marked with the new managedresource interface will have startmanagedresource and stopmanagedresource called appropriately
this allows for only the flow components specifically marked by the developer as having a managedresource to be managed in this way
exactly the same as option above but rather than adding to the existing flow interface create another managedflow interface with the new startmanagedresources and stopmanagedresources methods
although this creates a clearer distinction between a management operation and a business event operation it adds complexity to the implementation that is not otherwise required
option is the selected approach with option easily migrated to should we need to make this distinction
the attached diagram updatedflowimplementation.jpg details the additions described in red

summary: file based connector delivery bug when file exists on target system and overwrite is set to false
description: to be confirmed but i believe a bug has been introduced into the file delivery aspect shared by both the ftp and sftp connectors
the file delivery has two methods called to coordinate the transactional delivery of a file
performexecute is the first method invoked within the execution of the flow
when called it delivers a temp file to the file system if that temp file does not already exist
if it does exist and the overwrite flag is set to true then it is simply overwritten

if the overwrite flag is set to false then it will correctly rollback and rety or whatever action is docommit is the second method invoked but not directly within the flow it is invoked by the transaction manager
this method renames the temp file to the real file name if the file exists and overwrite is true then the file is simply overwritten
if the overwrite is false then an exception is thrown back to the transaction manager

problem here is that a the transaction manager will not retry a commit it will simply rollback the whole transaction and b a previously raised issue refers to the file connectors not recovering correctly so we are left with a stopped flow outcome potentially heuristic which requires manual intervention
resolution would ideally be to sort out the transaction recovery however this may not be so simple
a quick work around would be to check for both the temp file name and the real file name on the initial performexecute if the overwrite is false
note this is only an issue when the overwrite is false
